Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Frugivory networks and the assembly rules during early plant community assembly
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how tropical forests regenerate after clearing is crucial to the conservation of natural resources and biodiversity. In the tropics, seed dispersal by birds helps certain trees to spread back into deforested areas and regenerate forests. The unique feature of this study will be to ask what role fruit-eating birds can play overall in tropical forest regeneration. The research will go beyond separate studies of individual plants and birds to study the combined role of birds as dispersers in a whole forest community. Working in deforested pastures in Puerto Rico, researchers will follow the behavior of birds and the seasonality of fruit production by trees, measure the abundance of incoming seeds of different tree species, and add seeds to test whether dispersal is limiting regeneration. The project will also use an innovative method involving the labeling of seeds with stable isotopes to follow the actual movement of seeds by birds. Results will contribute new knowledge about the dynamics of tropical forests, including the interactions between plants and animals and how species assemble into forests on open land.
Most tropical forests worldwide are secondary forests that have regenerated following the abandonment of agriculture and grazing. Understanding what drives regeneration will help land managers accelerate the recovery of forests and counteract continuing forest loss. The project will also incorporate students and citizens into the data collection activities and serve as an education and information dissemination tool. Research activities will train a Ph.D. student and provide hands-on experiences for other students and the general public through a partnership with local educational organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes: How fruit-eating birds that disperse seeds influence plant communities is critical to understand plant community ecology because the vast majority of tree species in the world depend on these birds to disperse their seeds. In this project, we conducted field experiments and observational studies for three years to examine how birds that feed on fruit and disperse the seeds of plants influence the composition and relative abundance of tropical plant species. Using a series of experimental forest-regeneration plots placed in deforested areas in Aguadilla Puerto Rico, we measured - for the first time - the amount of compositional changes that fruit-eating birds impose on regenerating plant communities. Activities included measuring the monthly fruit-production of a sample of 365 tropical trees, conducting controlled seed-addition experiments and comparing the resulting plant communities to those that develop from the natural activity of seed-dispersing birds, studying the foraging activity and behavior of seed-dispersing birds, and conducting seed predation experiments.

With the forest-regeneration experiment we tested the null hypothesis that birds feed on fruit randomly from the available fruiting plant species. If birds are random in how they feed, seed dispersal patterns should mirror the availability of plants around each experimental plot. In contrast, we found that seed dispersal by birds create plant communities that are significantly more diverse than expected by the diversity and fecundity of surrounding plant communities. We also found that two generalist bird species – the Grey Kingbird and the Northern Mockingbird – are responsible for the effects since their activity at experimental plots was positively correlated with both the diversity of seeds arriving and the diversity of plants that get established. Observational data on foraging birds corroborate the disproportionate importance of these two bird species, because they are responsible for the majority of seed dispersal interactions taking place in the plant community in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico. Furthermore, results from seed-predation experiments show that seed predation occurring after seeds are dispersed by birds does not significantly modify the plant-regeneration templates set by avian frugivory and seed dispersal. We conclude that abundant generalist birds are of critical importance for initiating tropical forest-regeneration processes and diversifying communities from the start.

Broader Impacts: The project fostered the collaboration between faculty at a large land grant institution (Penn State University) and a small liberal arts college (Presbyterian College), and provided training and research opportunity for one postdoctoral scholar, two graduate students, two undergraduate students, and one REU student.  The PI organized and offered two special courses on “study design and analysis of ecological data” for Latin American ecology students at a major state universities in Peru (Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos, 11-15 Dec 2014) and the Dominican Republic (Universidad Autónoma de Santo Domingo, 3-5 Jun 2015). Results were disseminated in professional conferences, departmental seminars at major national and international universities, and peer-reviewed journals.
